questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a pelvic mass that was incidentally found on imaging during an evaluation for abdominal discomfort. She is postmenopausal and denies any abnormal bleeding or significant weight loss. A pelvic ultrasound reveals a solid, well-circumscribed ovarian mass. The mass is surgically excised, and the histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Brenner tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brenner tumors are benign ovarian neoplasms characterized by nests of transitional cells within a dense fibrous stroma. These tumors are typically asymptomatic and are often discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery for other conditions. The histological appearance of transitional cells in nests with a coffee bean nuclear appearance is distinctive for Brenner tumors.Top of Form
  • ➤ Brenner tumors are benign ovarian neoplasms characterized by nests of transitional cells within a dense fibrous stroma.
  • ➤ These tumors are typically asymptomatic and are often discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery for other conditions.
  • ➤ The histological appearance of transitional cells in nests with a coffee bean nuclear appearance is distinctive for Brenner tumors.Top of Form

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic kidney disease undergoes evaluation of his renal function. A study is performed to assess the glomerular filtration barrier's selective permeability. The graph below shows the relative filterability of different substances through the kidney based on their molecular size and charge, with 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Based on the graph, which of the following correctly identifies substances A, B, and C?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Polycationic, neutral, polyanionic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged, which increases the filterability of polycationic substances and decreases the filterability of polyanionic substances, especially as their size increases.
  • ➤ The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged, which increases the filterability of polycationic substances and decreases the filterability of polyanionic substances, especially as their size increases.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus is scheduled for a total knee replacement. He receives spinal anesthesia with 0.75% bupivacaine at the L3-L4 level. Shortly after the procedure, he begins to experience difficulty breathing, profound hypotension (BP 70/40 mmHg), and bradycardia (HR 45 bpm). He becomes increasingly lethargic, and his oxygen saturation drops to 85%. What is the most likely complication the patient is experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High spinal anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High spinal anesthesia is a serious complication that occurs when the local anesthetic spreads beyond the intended level, leading to extensive sympathetic blockade, severe hypotension, bradycardia, and respiratory difficulty. Immediate recognition and intervention, including supportive measures such as fluids, vasopressors, and airway management, are critical in managing this condition.
  • ➤ High spinal anesthesia is a serious complication that occurs when the local anesthetic spreads beyond the intended level, leading to extensive sympathetic blockade, severe hypotension, bradycardia, and respiratory difficulty.
  • ➤ Immediate recognition and intervention, including supportive measures such as fluids, vasopressors, and airway management, are critical in managing this condition.

questions.text: A 14-year-old adolescent presents to the clinic with a unique set of symptoms. He reports experiencing episodes of sudden and uncontrollable muscle weakness, often triggered by laughter or other strong emotions. During these episodes, he remains conscious but is unable to move, which lasts for a few seconds to a minute. Additionally, he describes vivid and dream-like hallucinations that occur when falling asleep or waking up. He also mentions excessive daytime sleepiness, often struggling to stay awake during lectures. Which of the following conditions best explains this tetrad of symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Narcolepsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Narcolepsy is a sleep disorder characterized by a tetrad of symptoms: excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic or hypnopompic hallucinations and sleep paralysis. Recognizing this cluster of symptoms is essential for diagnosing narcolepsy and differentiating it from other conditions that may present with overlapping features.
  • ➤ Narcolepsy is a sleep disorder characterized by a tetrad of symptoms: excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic or hypnopompic hallucinations and sleep paralysis.
  • ➤ Recognizing this cluster of symptoms is essential for diagnosing narcolepsy and differentiating it from other conditions that may present with overlapping features.

  • ➤ Tamsulosin (Drug C) is an α1-adrenergic antagonist used to treat urinary symptoms in BPH.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with severe brain injury exhibits decerebrate posturing. According to the Herrington classification of decerebrate rigidity, which of the following is NOT a characteristic of this condition?

questions.text: In a city with a population of 30,000, there were 520 births in a year, including 30 stillbirths. The total number of deaths was 300, of which 40 occurred within the first 28 days of life, and another 50 died after 28 days but before completing their first year of life. What is the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) in this area?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is a vital public health indicator that measures the number of infant deaths per 1,000 live births. It provides insight into the health and well-being of infants within a population, reflecting the quality of healthcare services.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with diabetes presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up. The physician orders a plasma glucose test to monitor her blood sugar levels. The nurse draws blood using the vacutainer shown in the image, which contains an anticoagulant and an additional agent to prevent glycolysis. Which of the following anticoagulants is most likely present in this vacutainer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Potassium oxalate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For accurate plasma glucose estimation, a vacutainer containing potassium oxalate as the anticoagulant, along with sodium fluoride as a glycolysis inhibitor, is used. This combination prevents clotting and preserves glucose levels, ensuring reliable test results, especially in diabetic patients.
  • ➤ For accurate plasma glucose estimation, a vacutainer containing potassium oxalate as the anticoagulant, along with sodium fluoride as a glycolysis inhibitor, is used.
  • ➤ This combination prevents clotting and preserves glucose levels, ensuring reliable test results, especially in diabetic patients.

questions.text: Which of the following components is found in a ganglioside, a lipid that accumulates in Tay-Sachs disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of severe, non-pitting facial swelling and abdominal pain. She reports that these episodes often occur spontaneously or after minor trauma. There is no associated urticaria or pruritus. Her father and sister have experienced similar symptoms. Laboratory testing reveals low levels of C4 during an acute attack. Which of the following protein deficiencies is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C1 inhibitor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hereditary angioedema is most commonly caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor (C1-INH), leading to episodes of severe swelling without urticaria. This condition involves abnormal complement system activation, particularly affecting the regulation of bradykinin, which leads to angioedema.
  • ➤ Hereditary angioedema is most commonly caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor (C1-INH), leading to episodes of severe swelling without urticaria.
  • ➤ This condition involves abnormal complement system activation, particularly affecting the regulation of bradykinin, which leads to angioedema.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine wellness visit. She feels well, has no medical problems, and takes no medications. Her medical history includes an episode of pyelonephritis treated with a 3-day hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics after the birth of her last child at age 42. Physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis shows trace leukocyte esterase, and two subsequent urine cultures reveal more than 105 cfu/mL of Escherichia coli. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.correct_answer: D. No further evaluation or treatment
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asymptomatic bacteriuria should not be treated in most patients, except in specific populations such as pregnant women and those undergoing urologic procedures. Treating ASB in other populations does not improve outcomes and can lead to antibiotic resistance.
  • ➤ Asymptomatic bacteriuria should not be treated in most patients, except in specific populations such as pregnant women and those undergoing urologic procedures.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, and dilated pupils. He admits to recent drug use. Which drug is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine intoxication is characterized by euphoria, sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis), paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) auditory hallucinations, tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin).
  • ➤ Cocaine intoxication is characterized by euphoria, sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis), paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) auditory hallucinations, tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with progressive involuntary movements, personality changes, and cognitive decline. His father had similar symptoms and passed away in his 50s. An MRI of the brain is performed, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and MRI findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Huntington’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Huntington’s disease is characterized by caudate nucleus atrophy and resultant enlargement of the lateral ventricles on MRI. This finding, along with a clinical presentation of chorea, cognitive decline, and psychiatric changes, is diagnostic of Huntington’s disease.
  • ➤ Huntington’s disease is characterized by caudate nucleus atrophy and resultant enlargement of the lateral ventricles on MRI.
  • ➤ This finding, along with a clinical presentation of chorea, cognitive decline, and psychiatric changes, is diagnostic of Huntington’s disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female undergoes carpal tunnel release surgery under a Bier's block using 50 mL of 0.5% lidocaine. Shortly after the tourniquet is inflated and the anesthetic is injected, the patient begins to complain of ringing in her ears, dizziness and a metallic taste in her mouth. Moments later, she becomes agitated and starts experiencing muscle twitching, followed by tonic-clonic seizures. Her blood pressure drops to 80/50 mmHg and her heart rate increases to 120 bpm. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans.B) Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is a potentially life-threatening condition that can occur during regional anesthesia procedures like Bier's block. It presents with neurological symptoms such as tinnitus, dizziness and seizures, followed by cardiovascular collapse. Prompt recognition and treatment with intralipid therapy and supportive care are essential to prevent severe outcomes.
  • ➤ Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is a potentially life-threatening condition that can occur during regional anesthesia procedures like Bier's block.
  • ➤ Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST)
  • ➤ It presents with neurological symptoms such as tinnitus, dizziness and seizures, followed by cardiovascular collapse. Prompt recognition and treatment with intralipid therapy and supportive care are essential to prevent severe outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about NSAIDs is false?

options.label: A
options.text: They interfere with the antihypertensive effect of diuretics.

options.label: B
options.text: NSAIDs are useful in neuropathic pain.

options.label: C
options.text: NSAIDs should be avoided in renal disease as they can cause nephrotoxicity.

options.label: D
options.text: Many NSAIDs can be used topically.

questions.correct_answer: B. NSAIDs are useful in neuropathic pain.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NSAIDs are not effective for neuropathic pain; they are primarily used for inflammatory and nociceptive pain. NSAIDs can interfere with the antihypertensive effects of diuretics and pose a risk of nephrotoxicity, particularly in patients with renal disease. Topical NSAIDs are an option for localized pain management with fewer systemic effects.
  • ➤ NSAIDs are not effective for neuropathic pain; they are primarily used for inflammatory and nociceptive pain.
  • ➤ NSAIDs can interfere with the antihypertensive effects of diuretics and pose a risk of nephrotoxicity, particularly in patients with renal disease.
  • ➤ Topical NSAIDs are an option for localized pain management with fewer systemic effects.

questions.text: A junior resident accidentally sustains a needle stick injury while drawing blood from a patient known to be HBsAg positive. questions.text: Which of the following statements about nesiritide is false ?

options.label: B
options.text: It can be used in decompensated CHF

questions.text: After a weekend drinking binge, a 45-year-old man presents to the hospital with abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. On physical examination, he has tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. Laboratory tests reveal an amylase level of 25,000 U/L (normal < 180 U/L). The patient is diagnosed with acute pancreatitis and is medically managed. He is sent home after 1 week of hospitalization. A follow-up CT scan done 4 weeks later reveals the findings shown in the image. The patient is currently asymptomatic. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: No intervention is warranted at this time

questions.correct_answer: D. No intervention is warranted at this time
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) No intervention is warranted at this time

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Observation without intervention is the appropriate initial management for an asymptomatic pancreatic pseudocyst detected following acute pancreatitis. Most pseudocysts resolve spontaneously within 6-12 weeks, and intervention should be delayed to allow for the possibility of spontaneous resolution and to permit cyst wall maturation if intervention becomes necessary.
  • ➤ Observation without intervention is the appropriate initial management for an asymptomatic pancreatic pseudocyst detected following acute pancreatitis.
  • ➤ Most pseudocysts resolve spontaneously within 6-12 weeks, and intervention should be delayed to allow for the possibility of spontaneous resolution and to permit cyst wall maturation if intervention becomes necessary.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with COPD has been on long-term oxygen therapy, leading to suspected lung injury from oxygen toxicity. It is noted that his glycolysis rate decreases in response to the hyperoxia. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?

questions.text: A hospital administrator is conducting an annual review of the facility's waste management practices to ensure compliance with environmental and health regulations. questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn presents with lethargy, poor feeding, vomiting, and seizures. Laboratory tests reveal hyperammonemia and elevated plasma citrulline levels. questions.text: A 68-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever and nausea.
